'No capes!' Edna Mode is a legendary cha: Syndrome being the fanboy Buddy all grown up is such a great villain origin story.
The family dynamic in this is so real. I love their dinner table arguments.
When Bob finds out Syndrome has killed off all the other supers... that was dark.
Dash running on water for the first time was an epic moment.
The whole 'I work alone' thing really coming back to bite Mr. Incredible in the butt was perfect.
The score for this movie is amazing. It has such a cool retro spy vibe.
Elastigirl breaking into the base is peak spy action. She's the real hero of this movie.
Frozone is the coolest character. 'Where is my super suit?!'
The final battle with the Omnidroid in the city is one of the best superhero fights ever.
This movie is a perfect commentary on mediocrity vs. excellence.
Jack-Jack's powers finally activating at the end to save himself from Syndrome was so chaotic and awesome.
The scene where Bob is working at the insurance company is painfully relatable.
The whole family finally working together in their matching suits is so satisfying to watch.
Violet finally gaining confidence and using her force fields to protect her family is a great character arc.
Syndrome getting yeeted by a jet engine because of his cape is the ultimate irony.
The design of the Omnidroid is so simple but so effective and menacing.
Elastigirl's 'no, I'm the mom' speech on the plane is iconic.
The action sequences are better than most live-action superhero movies.
The moment the whole family combines their powers to take down the Omnidroid was a chef's kiss moment.
Edna Mode's house is an architectural masterpiece.
The plane crash scene was surprisingly intense for a kids' movie.
The first 15 minutes showing the 'glory days' and then the downfall is a great setup.
The Underminer at the end is the perfect setup for a sequel.
The movie has such a great, timeless art style.
Mirage's change of heart and helping the Incredibles escape was a nice touch.
The '100-mile Dash' scene is pure joy and excitement.
Syndrome's plan to sell his tech so everyone can be super is a fascinating villain motive.
Bob trying to relive his glory days in secret is a classic mid-life crisis story, but with superheroes.
The Omnidroid learning and adapting to Mr. Incredible's moves makes it a truly formidable villain.
I love how each family member's power reflects their personality.
The family realizing they are stronger together is the core message of the film.
The scene where Bob thinks his family is dead is heartbreaking.
'You got me monologuing!' is an all-time great villain line.
The movie is just pure fun from start to finish.
Syndrome's death is one of the more brutal endings for a Pixar villain.
The bond between Frozone and the Incredibles is so wholesome.
Elastigirl turning into a parachute and a boat is so creative.
The movie has so much heart. It's really about a family learning to be a family again.
Jack-Jack fighting the raccoon in the sequel is a payoff from the powers reveal here. So good.
The interview segments at the beginning are a great way to introduce the characters.
The scene where Bob is slowly getting crushed by the Omnidroid is super tense.
The government's superhero relocation program is such a cool concept.
Syndrome's island base is a perfect evil lair.
The moment when Violet can't make a forcefield to save the plane is a raw moment of self-doubt.
'Honey? Where's my super suit?' is quoted in my house daily.
The design of the 'old' costumes vs. the new Edna ones is a great detail.
Syndrome's whole plan hinged on him being the hero, which is a classic narcissist move.
The action is great, but the quiet character moments are what make the movie special.
The final victory feels so earned because the whole family had to grow to achieve it.
The way the kids discover their parents' secret lives is so well done.
The movie is just packed with memorable quotes and scenes.
The music really makes you feel like you're in a classic Bond movie.
Syndrome's obsession with Mr. Incredible is what leads to his downfall.
The family argument at dinner is one of the most realistic family scenes in any movie.
Elastigirl realizing Bob is lying about his 'business trip' is a great detective moment.
This movie is a love letter to Silver Age comics.
Syndrome's zero-point energy gauntlets are a cool piece of tech.
The film perfectly balances high-stakes action with relatable family problems.
The ending, with the whole family ready to fight as a team, is the perfect final shot.
Edna is the real MVP of this movie.
The way the Omnidroid outsmarts itself in the final battle is a brilliant resolution.
The movie is smart, funny, and has a ton of heart.
'When everyone's super... no one will be.' Such a great villain line.
The montage of Bob getting back in shape is hilarious and inspiring.
The reveal that the robot was specifically designed to kill him was a big yikes moment.
The characters are so well-written and developed.
The final battle shows that the family is their own best super team.
This is easily one of Pixar's best films. A classic.
Syndrome's whole plan to replace the supers is born out of pure rejection. Sad and twisted.
Frozone's powers are just the coolest. Literally.
The way they use their powers in everyday life (like Violet's invisibility) is so clever.
A perfect superhero movie that's also a perfect family movie.
Syndrome trying to kidnap Jack-Jack and then getting wrecked by his powers is so satisfying.
The animation holds up so well. It still looks fantastic.
The moment the family decides to fight together is the turning point of the whole film.
This movie has a great message about embracing what makes you special.
The way the Omnidroid is defeated by turning its own weapon against it is poetic.
The world-building is subtle but so effective.
Syndrome's obsession is a cautionary tale about meeting your heroes.
The family's powers get them into trouble but also save them in the end.
The whole movie is a masterclass in storytelling.
The final shot of them putting on their masks together gives me goosebumps every time.
The dynamic between Bob and Helen feels like a real, lived-in marriage.
'I never look back, darling. It distracts from the now.' Edna is a queen.
The movie is just endlessly rewatchable.
Jack-Jack's babysitter having to deal with his emerging powers is a hilarious short film that pays this off.
The perfect mix of action, comedy, and heartfelt emotion.
Syndrome's death is a direct result of him not listening to Edna's 'no capes' rule.
Brad Bird is a genius. That is all.
The way the family has to hide their true selves from the world adds a great layer of conflict.
This is not just a great animated movie, it's a great movie, period.
The final battle isn't just about saving the city, it's about saving their family.
